Scale.0001.description:
Static content detected.

Your current approach of serving static content directly might lead to increased costs, performance issues, maintenance challenges (requiring application redeployment for content changes), and security risks.

Consider moving static content to Azure Blob Storage and adding Azure CDN.
Scale.0001.label: Static content detected

Connection.0001.description:
Connection string detected. It may not be available when your app is migrated to Azure.

Review and ensure it works from Azure. If you are connecting to a database, you might need to migrate the database to Azure. There are multiple ways to do it:
    1. Migrate to Azure SQL Database for additional benefits (see the link below).
    2. Consider Azure SQL Managed Instance if you need features that are not available in Azure SQL Database and you don’t want to use a VM.
    3. Migrate your database servers directly to SQL Server on Azure VMs.

To assess database migration effort, you can use Azure Migrate tool, see the link below.
Connection.0001.label: Connection string is detected

links.title: Migrate SQL Server database to Azure

Local.0004.description:
Logging to local or network paths detected.

Logging APIs that write to disk might not work on Azure App Service or Container.

Use logging that stores logs in locations outside of the host unless its specifically required by your app. You can also use logging capabilities embedded in Azure, such as Azure App Service logging or Application Insights.

For migrating to AKS, use LogMonitor tool that can capture logs written to files, the console, or write logs and redirect them to Azure.
Local.0004.label: Logging to local or network paths detected

Local.0003.description:
Your application has local or network IO operations.

IO operations outside of the application folder might not be available on Azure App Service. Review and ensure IO APIs are attempting to access paths that will be available when your app is running on App Service sandbox. If you choose the containerized hosting option, your scenario still might be broken or have scalability issues.

Possible solutions:
    1. Files that the application needs can be deployed with the application or put in Azure Storage. You can use Azure Storage File Shares as a drop-in replacement for on-premises file share.
    2. Other services that the application depends on might need to be migrated to Azure, this way you will get the benefit of lower latency in the cloud.
    3. If your application needs to depend on services that run on-premise, you can connect your Azure and local networks with ExpressRoute, Hybrid Connections, or VPN solutions.
Local.0003.label: Local or network IO operations detected

Local.0007.description:
Local OS environment access detected.

When running in Azure App Service environment, your application can read environment variables that you define in App Service settings. Using environment API other than reading environment variables might indicate that your application depends on some local machine’s features and might be broken on App Service sandbox or not scale well. Review your scenarios and either refactor them to be more cloud friendly or choose the option in App Service to host your application in the sandbox for Windows Container Web Apps.

If you choose to use other Azure hosting options such as Azure Container Apps (ACA) or Azure Kubernetes Service (AKS), environment APIs might work, however scaling still might be an issue.
Local.0007.label: Local OS environment access detected

links.title: App Service sandbox for Windows Container Web Apps

Database.0001.description:
Database dependency detected.

Ensure the database is available/reachable on Azure. If it is not, there are multiple ways you can move your data to Azure.

If it is SQL database:
    1. Migrate to Azure SQL Database.
    2. Consider Azure SQL Managed Instance if you need features that are not available in Azure SQL Database and you don’t want to use a VM.
    3. Migrate your database servers directly to SQL Server on Azure VMs.

If it is NoSql database use Azure CosmosDB.

To assess database migration effort, you can use Azure Migrate tool, see the link below.
Database.0001.label: Database dependency detected

links.title: Migrate SQL Server database to Azure

Connection.0002.description:
Your application depends on environment variables which may also need to be set in the Azure environment it is deployed to.

Ensure you have a plan for setting those variables. Depending on the Azure solution you have chosen, there are different ways you can work with environment variables:
    - For Azure App Service use Azure App Service environment variables (see a link below).
    - For Azure Container App (ACA) or Azure Kubernetes Service (AKS) you can set environment variables in container instances (see link below).

Alternatively, you can use Azure services that can share settings between application such as Azure App Configuration and Azure Key Vault.
Connection.0002.label: Environment variables dependency detected

links.title: Environment variables and app settings in Azure App Service
